about.title: Secure-by-design engineering
paragraphs: I’m a Master 1 Informatique student at Aix-Marseille Université, specializing in secure software, resilient infrastructure, and AI-assisted defenses.
My academic journey spans secure web applications with Flask/JavaScript, advanced Java development, cryptography, and network programming.
Beyond code, I thrive in multicultural contexts, speak Arabic, French, and English, and stay sharp through running and strength training.

threat_modeling.title: Threat modeling for lean teams
threat_modeling.excerpt: How I build lightweight threat models that evolve with startup roadmaps and still satisfy auditors.
content: Threat modeling is only useful if the exercise stays alive as the roadmap evolves. In this article I show the template I use with small teams: one page, three layers (assets, attack paths, control debt) and a weekly update cadence. The goal is to turn the model into a living prioritization tool, not a static document.
I also cover how we used lightweight automation (GitHub issues + miro snapshots) to keep auditors happy without locking the team into heavyweight tooling.

ai_security.title: AI-assisted detection without the hype
ai_security.excerpt: Lessons from prototyping a DDoS classifier and wiring the insights into day-to-day operations.
content: Building an AI-driven detector starts with curating the right features. I explain how we gathered high-signal data from load balancers and why feature engineering mattered more than model selection.
The second half focuses on deployment: surfacing explainable alerts in the SOC tooling and measuring precision/recall so the model actually earns analysts’ trust.

network_resilience.title: Designing resilient messaging layers
network_resilience.excerpt: Architectural patterns to keep distributed messaging steady when packets drop and nodes disappear.
content: Distributed messaging breaks in surprising ways. I share failure stories (packet storms, partial outages) and the three architectural levers that helped: quorum-based acknowledgements, adaptive back-pressure, and circuit breakers.
You’ll also find diagrams showing how observability hooks (synthetic publishers + latency histograms) gave us confidence when rolling out new regions.
